abstract.text: An object that manages an array of adjacent child views, and has a split view object for managing dividers between those views.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A split view controller manages a set of child views that it displays next to each other in a side-by-side or top-to-bottom arrangement.
A split view controller owns an array of split view items (
), each of which has a view controller (
) and corresponding view. The split view controller’s
object manages those child views and the dividers between them.
By default, a split view arranges its child views vertically from top to bottom. To specify a horizontal (side-by-side) arrangement, implement the
The split view controller serves as the delegate of its
object. If you override a split view delegate method, your override must call

To use a split view controller, you must use Auto Layout for the child views and to support animations that collapse and reveal child views. For example, if you design a layout that contains two views, a content area and an optional sidebar, you employ Auto Layout constraints to specify whether the content area shrinks or remains the same size when the sidebar becomes visible.
A split view controller employs lazy loading of its views. For example, adding a collapsed split view item as a new child doesn’t load the associated view until it shows.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A set of methods that support the mediation of a custom segue.
A view that arranges two or more views in a linear stack running horizontally or vertically.
A Boolean value that determines the geometric orientation of the split view’s dividers.
An object that manages an array of adjacent child views, and has a split view object for managing dividers between those views.
Adds a split view item to the end of the array of split view items.
The default value to apply to a dimension.
Adds a split view item to the array of split view items at the specified index position.
The minimum thickness for a sidebar before it automatically collapses.
Removes a specified split view item from the split view controller.
The split view that the split view controller manages.
Returns the corresponding split view item for the specified child view controller of the split view controller.
The array of split view items that correspond to the split view controller’s child view controllers.
Collapses or expands the first sidebar in the split view controller using an animation.
Configures the split view controller after its view loads into memory.
A set of optional methods that a delegate of a split view implements.
An item in a split view controller.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A protocol that a custom class can adopt to manage the enabled state of a UI element.
A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.
Build a structured user interface that simplifies navigation in your app.

abstract.text: Access the split view controller’s implementations of protocol methods.
A true value.

The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
